Dear all, 

I have this interesting tsuba posted on Nihontostudy at:

All A=
lbums  | Photo Albums > Sosidore > Iron Tsuba Dragon  
 
Anyone well versed=
 in Chinese artifacts knows this tsuba is an 
unusual one. I would like to =
give some clue so that readers of this 
message would came up with similar =
beliefe as I did.

1. Chinese emperor was the only one who is entitled to p=
ut dragon 
decors on everything he owned. 
2. However dragons could also pu=
t to use as icons by other persons or 
entities only if the number of drago=
n's fingers reduced to either 4 
or 3. Five fingers claws must not be used =
in any dragon unless the 
owner of that dragon design is Chinese emperor hi=
mself. Violation of 
such rule was subject to capital punishment.
3. There =
used to be a continued flow of sword import from Japan 
dating back more th=
an a thousand years.
4. Swords as possibly one of the contributions to Chin=
ese emperor 
during Qing Dynasty would demand unique design for their tsuba=
s. 
Guess what design would it use?
5. Any contribution to the king would b=
ear no signature of the 
artist. Guess what? This elegant iron tsuba bear n=
o signature on 
neither side.  
6. I am in no position to do the authentica=
tion on the style of the 
dragon shown on this tsuba. Somehow its style poi=
sed to resemble the 
one shown on Meiji coins. There is strong likelihood t=
hat this tsuba 
was of Japan origin dating back to late 19th century.
7. Gu=
ess who is in the position in Japan to offer this tsuba as part 
of a sword=
 to Chinese emperor then?

I hope you enjoy as much as I when pondering the=
 answers to those 
questions. You probably would find some interesting part=
 of details 
missing. Readers and I would like to hear them.

Now, it is ti=
me that tsuba expert and historians take over 
authentication processes fro=
m here. 

Chen, Ying-chaw
Taipei
